ORAL ANSWERS TO QUESTIONS

STATE OF ECONOMY AND HIGH OIL PRICES

     1.  Mr Inderjit Singh asked the Minister for Trade and Industry if he can provide an update on the state of the economy, especially after the recent downward revision of the projected growth numbers for 2005.

     2.  Dr Amy Khor Lean Suan asked the Minister for Trade and Industry (a) whether our economy has been and could be further affected by persistently high oil prices;  (b) if further downward revisions on our economic growth forecast this year are likely;  and (c) how will this affect job prospects.

     The Minister for Trade and Industry (Mr Lim Hng Kiang):  Mr Speaker, Sir, may I have your permission to take Question Nos. 1 and 2 together?

     Mr Speaker:  Yes.

     Mr Lim Hng Kiang:  Mr Speaker, Sir, in May, the MTI revised its forecast for economic growth this year to 2.5% to 4.5%.  This was a downward revision from the earlier forecast of between 3% and 5%.

 

Column: 733

  Two main reasons accounted for this revision.  First, output of the biomedical manufacturing cluster was expected to weaken this year, following a 26% gain in 2004.  This reflected planned changes in the production mix of pharmaceutical output this year.

 

     Second, a number of developments - especially high oil prices - had pointed to less buoyant economic growth for some of our major trading partners this year.

 

     Data available since the revision showed that lower output in the biomedical manufacturing cluster continued to persist.  Oil prices have also risen past the US$60 per barrel mark since early July.  Higher oil prices led a few major economies to downgrade their GDP growth forecasts or issue warnings of likely economic weakness recently.

 

     Nevertheless, based on our early estimates, we expect the second-quarter GDP growth to be better than the first quarter's, at about 3.9% compared to 2.8%.  This reflected stronger support from the services sectors, particularly the wholesale and retail trade sector.

 

     With economic growth for the first half of 2005 at an estimated 3.4%, MTI continues to expect full year growth to fall within the forecast range even if oil prices are maintained at current levels or even slightly higher to the end of the year.

 

     As an oil importing economy, Singapore cannot escape the negative impact of high oil prices.  However, unlike previous oil shocks, we expect the impact of the current high oil prices to be tempered.  During the oil shocks of the 1970s and the 1980s, high oil prices were the results of abrupt supply disruptions, and they led to widespread economic recessions.  In contrast, the high oil prices we face today are due to

Column: 734

strong economic growth in two of our major export markets - the US and China.  The demand for oil to fuel their economic growth has strained existing oil producing and refining capacities globally, leading to upward pressures on prices.  But this same growth also boosts the external demand for goods and services produced here, helping to support Singapore's economic growth.

 

     Oil prices are likely to remain high into the foreseeable future, due to the lead time needed for capacity expansion in the oil industry.  But as long as high oil prices are the result of strong demand, economic growth should continue in Singapore.  At this point, MTI also does not foresee the impact on the labour market here to be severe.

 

     A clearer picture of the economic outlook will emerge over the next few weeks as more data concerning second quarter growth comes in.  MTI will release the details of second quarter economic performance after National Day.  It will also announce the latest forecast for full year growth for 2005.

 

     Mr Inderjit Singh (Ang Mo Kio):  Sir, I would like to ask the Minister on the outlook for manufacturing, particularly electronics manufacturing, in light of a few closures of some multinational companies who are relocating from Singapore to other countries.  Is this trend increasing or do we see manufacturing strengthening again in Singapore?

     Mr Lim Hng Kiang:  Mr Speaker, Sir, manufacturing output for the first half of this year remains soft compared to last year.  This is because last year we had a very high base of growth.  This year, for the first half, we are growing at below 4%.  But we expect the second half to be better and we therefore expect manufacturing to contribute significantly to our growth forecast of 2.5% and 4.5%.

 

Column: 735

     Looking forward, we expect manufacturing to continue to play an important role in Singapore by contributing between 25% and 27% of our GDP.  There will be some relocations of the low-end value-added sectors but we have a very strong investment pipeline and investments continue to be very vigorous in the manufacturing sector generating good jobs for Singaporeans.  So the outlook for manufacturing remains positive.

     Dr Amy Khor Lean Suan (Hong Kah):  Sir, I would like to ask the Minister if the improved growth in the second quarter, which was driven by the services sector, is likely to be sustainable, going forward into the rest of the year and, also, if there is any evidence that the SMEs are more hard-hit by the negative impact caused by oil prices.

     Mr Lim Hng Kiang:  Mr Speaker, Sir, I believe our economy is as diversified as you can make it to be and, therefore, as we go forward, we expect some sectors to suffer from low growth but other sectors to be buoyant.  In this way, we continue to achieve our medium term growth prospects.

 

     Going forward, the services sector looks promising, particularly the tourism sector is experiencing very good growth.  Business and financial services are also doing well.  There is no reason for us to think that the services sector should slow down significantly going to the second quarter.  We continue to look forward to the contribution of the services sector towards our economy.

 

     I think, overall, the Singapore economy is performing reasonably well.  We must not expect a repeat of last year's very high growth.  This year, we expect growth to consolidate and therefore 2.5% to 4.5% growth is a very decent performance.

Column: 736

     Mr Inderjit Singh:   Sir, could the Minister elaborate a bit on the biomedical sector?  I could not get a feel of whether this was a short-term downturn or it was a volatility that we did not expect.  Or is it expected to decline further?  If the Minister could give us an insight of how this sector is going to perform, it will be useful.

     Mr Lim Hng Kiang:  Mr Speaker, Sir, we have explained the volatility faced by our biomedical cluster several times.  First of all, the biomedical cluster contributes about 5% of our GDP.  It is not a small sector.  But, unfortunately, the plants that we have are producing active pharmaceutical ingredients and this tends to be done on a batch basis.  It is not a continuous sustained production, ie, they produce batch by batch.  So every time there is a major run, we see very good growth.  As they retool the manufacturing plants to cater for the next batch, there is a period in which the output slows down. 

 

     Last year, for example, a few plants came into operation and that gave us a very high growth.  This year, if we can continue to sustain that same output, I think we would have done very well.  But that means the rate of growth is not there and, again, because of this batch production, we do see some quarters showing a negative output.  But this is the nature of the biomedical cluster in Singapore.  The volatility will reduce as we grow the base of the biomedical sector to include contributions from the biotech sector and the medical devices which tend to be more steady.  But if we are producing the active ingredients, then we have to ride this volatility.

     Mr Leong Horn Kee (Bishan-Toa Payoh):  Sir, I would like to refer the Minister to the figure he mentioned about our GDP growth is likely to be 2.5% to 4.5%.  He said earlier that MTI may give a closer forecast.  Could the Minister affirm that figure?

 

Column: 737

     I would also like to ask him whether there are any other bright spots that he can foresee coming up this year.  For example, would there be a recovery in the construction sector? 

 

     Finally, would there be any follow-through impact as we expect to see coming soon from the construction of the two integrated resorts?

     Mr Lim Hng Kiang:  Mr Speaker, Sir, as I have explained, we have already achieved 3.4% growth for the first half.  So that is squarely in the middle of the band in our forecast range of 2.5% to 4.5%.  Going forward, we will get the data of the second quarter over the next few weeks and therefore we should be able to confirm the second quarter growth figures by mid-August.  I think if that figure confirms our flash forecast, which is what we put out recently - the 3.9% growth for the second quarter is just a flash estimate - then I think we have a very solid first half growth. 

 

     We do not expect to see a significant downturn in the second half.  We need a very big downturn to bring us below the 2.5-4.5% range.  If any of the Members were to do their arithmetic,  with 3.4% growth in the first half, we are obviously in a very good position to achieve at least 2.5% growth for the year.

 

     As for achieving the higher end of the range, it will depend on a few sectors that may pick up.   The manufacturing sector looks very strong.  As Members know, our marine engineering companies still continue to get good orders and good growth.   Among the manufacturing sector, the electronics sector, some analysts think that the second half will be better than the first half.  By and large, we do not see a significant slowdown.  In fact, the assessment is that the second half ought to be better than the first half.  So

Column: 738

we can be cautiously optimistic about the growth prospects for the whole year.

 

     As for specifics, like the construction sector, I think this will really have to depend on growth in the private sector.  The Government projects are already in the Budget book and so people in the industry know what are the projects in the pipeline.

 

     As for the impact of the integrated resorts, the physical construction will not take place till one or two years down the road.  So it will not have an impact on this year's figures.

 

 

     Mr Inderjit Singh:  Sir, for the little growth that we are expecting this year,  does the Minister expect the growth to add any significant number of jobs or are we going to see a jobless type of growth?

     Mr Lim Hng Kiang:  Mr Speaker, Sir, we expect the employment creation to be similar to what we have, ie, commensurate with a growth rate of around 2.5% to 4.5%.  It will not have the kind of job creation that we saw last year.  But at the same time, we expect to see good job creation this year.

Column: 738

INCREASE IN ELECTRICITY TARIFFS

         3.  Mr Ong Kian Min asked the Minister for Trade and Industry what are the main reasons for the sharp increase in electricity tariffs for the period 1st July to 30th September 2005 and whether the financial impact of such increases can be mitigated for ordinary households.

     Mr Ong Kian Min (Tampines):  Sir, before I ask my question, I would like to declare that I am a director of Senoko Power Ltd, a Temasek-owned power generation company.  Question No. 3, Sir.

     Mr Lim Hng Kiang:  Mr Speaker, Sir, fuel cost makes up about half the cost of electricity. Our fuel sources for electricity

Column: 739

generation are oil and gas. Gas prices in Singapore are indexed to oil prices. An increase in oil prices will therefore lead to higher electricity prices. The electricity tariff for the period 1st July to 30th September 2005 increased by 14% mainly due to a 31% increase in fuel oil price over the previous quarter from  US$30.09 to US$39.32 per barrel.

 

        The Government will be giving utility rebates ranging between $60 and $200 - depending on HDB flat type - this month (July 2005) and in January next year (2006).  Unused rebates can be rolled over to the following months. These rebates, which were announced by the Prime Minister in his Budget Speech in February this year, will mitigate the financial impact of electricity price increases on households. In all, the rebates will cost the Government about $62 million.

 

    Singapore Power Services (SP Services) has also introduced the Pay-As-You-Use (PAYU) Metering Scheme on 16th May 2005 to help needy HDB households better manage their electricity consumption. This scheme enables HDB households whose electricity supply has been disconnected to be reconnected and have their arrears paid over time. This will help customers on the scheme consume electricity at levels they can afford.  


     In this period of high oil prices, it becomes all the more important that we adopt good energy conservation practices. Consumers should be more conscious about using energy-efficient electrical appliances. This includes opting for energy-labelled air conditioners and refrigerators, energy-saving lights, choosing the correct capacity of air-conditioner and refrigerator, and enabling "energy-saver" modes in their computers.  More information on energy conservation practices at home is available from the National Energy Efficiency Committee website.

 

 

 

Column: 740

     Mr Ong Kian Min:  Sir, I would like to ask the Minister three supplementary questions.  First, instead of introducing a 14% increase in tariff in one go, whether such a large double digit increase could or should be smoothened out and spread out over a period of time to mitigate the financial impact, not just on lower income households but on all families.

 

     Secondly, whether the present formula to determine the electricity tariffs for domestic households is too rigid as it is based on the average price of HSFO over a period of one month, say, the month of April, to lock in the rates for the period July to September.

 

     Thirdly, nothwithstanding that the new electricity tariff has been determined for the next three months, would there be any flexibility for a downward adjustment if oil prices were to retreat and come down during this period?

     Mr Lim Hng Kiang: Mr Speaker, Sir, the regime for setting electricity tariff prices has been in place for many years, and has served us well. It allows prices to move up in a smooth way as oil prices go up.  At the same time, it allows electricity prices to come down should oil prices come down.  As I indicated in my reply, even though oil prices have moved up by more than 30%, the electricity prices are adjusted upwards by 14%. So this is a result of the smoothening process.

 

      In answer to the second question, the tariff is set for three months.  And every time we do a revision, we look at what actually happens compared to what is forecasted and then make the adjustment.  So there is also an adjustment process with each review period.

 

     In answer to his third question, a downward adjustment will definitely take place if oil prices come down sharply. 

Column: 741

This is the automatic balancing that goes on with the review process.

 

     Mr Steve Chia Kiah Hong (Non-Constituency Member):  Sir, I just want to clarify with the Minister.  The 30% increase in the fuel oil price in the last quarter has caused this 14% increase in the electricity tariff.  Does it mean that as the price of fuel oil goes up and is expected to go up further that we could expect another tariff hike in the October-December period?  If so, what is the Government doing to mitigate this expected increase in the tariff in future?

     Mr Lim Hng Kiang: Sir, what the electricity tariff will be in future will depend on the behaviour of oil and gas prices which are linked to the high sulphur fuel oil prices.  As I indicated, there is a review mechanism, and we look at it quarter by quarter.  If the oil prices come down, then for subsequent quarters, we can see the electricity tariffs coming down too.

 

     There is another factor coming into play, ie, the competitive nature of the business.  If you read the Business Times report today, the article indicated that there is a huge supply capacity right now in our power generation sector, more than double the demand.  Therefore, there is a great deal of competition among the generating companies, and this has led to very competitive prices.  So the electricity tariff prices, for example, if we look back, say, in February 2001, it was the same price as today, whereas the oil prices in February 2001 were much lower than today. 

 

     So there are two factors at play here: one, the oil price and, secondly, the competitive forces.  Over the last few years, the competitive forces have helped to push the price down but, unfortunately,

Column: 742

we have this very strong headwind of higher oil prices.

     Sir, the autopsy on 2WO Teh concluded that he had died from sudden cardiac arrest that resulted from an acute myocardial infarction.  In layman's terms, he had suffered a heart attack.  The autopsy report on 3SG Ong is not yet ready as the Health Services Authority has not completed its investigations.

Conclusion

 

     We have been fortunate that there have been no attacks on Singapore.  But we cannot be complacent.  Our security agencies cannot be everywhere.  The people of Singapore play a critical role in partnership with the Government to keep Singapore safe and secure.  They do so in three important ways.  First, our people are the eyes and ears and the extended reach of our security agencies.  In this regard, I would like to urge all members of the public to continue to be vigilant and to report suspicious articles, persons or activities to the security agencies.  Second, our people are the arms and legs of the emergency response agencies.  Singaporeans should take an active interest in life-saving skills and participate in emergency response exercises organised in their neighbourhoods and constituencies.  Third, our people are the hearts and minds of the country.  The psychological resilience of Singaporeans and the unity and harmony among the different communities are crucial to see Singapore through crises.

     As background, Members of the House may recall that in November last year, we amended the Copyright Act to strengthen our copyright regime and to ensure that it remained relevant in the face of technological advancement.  Several of the amendments were also to fulfil the copyright aspects of our United States-Singapore Free Trade Agreement obligations.

Acquisition of knowledge

ORCHARD ROAD

(Measures to improve peak hour traffic flow)

     18.   Mr Ong Kian Min asked the Minister for Transport apart from the introduction of Electronic Road Pricing, what other measures will be taken to improve traffic flow along the Orchard Road belt during peak hours.

     Mr Yeo Cheow Tong:

     The LTA has conducted comprehensive traffic studies on Orchard Road and implemented numerous improvement schemes over the years.  These include making adjustments to the traffic lights at the junction of Orchard Road with Buyong Road and working with Centrepoint Development to ease localised congestion caused by taxis waiting at the Centrepoint taxi stand.  More recently, the LTA widened a section of Grange Road and converted Orchard Link into a one-way street to improve traffic flow in the Orchard Link area.

 

      With the emphasis on making Orchard Road our premier shopping street, it is important to continually improve the transportation system in Orchard Road to make the travelling experience of shoppers more pleasant.  As Orchard Road is a densely built-up area, it is not possible to rely solely on engineering initiatives or road expansion works to improve traffic flow. 

 

     Hence, there is a need to complement traffic measures with ERP.  The ERP strategy aims to reduce the overall traffic into Orchard Road by discouraging traffic that is just passing through Orchard Road into the CBD, as well as encouraging motorists to use public transport instead.  The LTA expects the volume of through traffic to Orchard Road to fall by 30%, resulting in improved traffic flow. 

 

     To make public transport more attractive, LTA will be implementing a full-day bus lane scheme along Orchard Road to improve the travel speeds of buses.  And as Members are aware, the Orchard Road corridor is already well served by the MRT system.

 

     Going forward, the LTA will continue to review ways to improve traffic flow in the Orchard Road belt.

PUBLIC TRANSPORT

(Concessions to senior citizens)

     20.   Dr Ong Seh Hong asked the Minister for Transport whether he will consider (i) extending simpler and broader-based concessions to senior citizens who use public transport such as MRT and buses; and (ii) urging transport operators to remove restrictions to which these concessions apply, specifically the time belts when these concessions kick in and, if not, whether the operators can adopt the same restrictions to avoid confusion for senior citizen commuters.

Column: 863

     Mr Yeo Cheow Tong:

     Travel concessions are granted by the public transport operators for senior citizens in Singapore to help lower the cost of travelling.  These schemes do not need approval by the Public Transport Council (PTC), as PTC regulates only the standard or full fares.  Any decision to improve on or to grant more concessions is therefore a matter for the transport operators to decide. 

 

      Dr Ong has asked if the transport operators could extend broader-based concessions and relax their restrictions on concession hours for senior citizens.   I will convey Dr Ong's suggestion to the PTOs. They would need to study the implications carefully, as further concessions for senior citizens would mean that they have to recover more from the full-fare paying passengers. Nevertheless, the transport operators have been extending the concessions for senior citizens over the years.  For example, up to five years ago, the special fares for senior citizens on Saturdays started only from 2.30 pm. The operators then extended Saturday concession hours to begin earlier, at 10 am.  And recently, both operators extended the Saturday concession to the whole day. This, together with the extension in concession hours during weekdays, will benefit about 140,000 senior citizens making trips on buses and trains each day.

 

     I agree with Dr Ong that it would be less confusing if the same concession restrictions or guidelines could be applied by both public transport operators.  We will continue to encourage the operators to work together to harmonise their concession schemes for the benefit of their commuters.

SINGAPOREAN PROFESSIONALS, MANAGERS AND EXECUTIVES

(Unemployment)

     30.   Mdm Ho Geok Choo asked the Minister for Manpower if he will provide a status report on (a) how many unemployed Singaporean professionals, managers and executives (PMEs) are aged above 40;  (b) what sectors do these unemployed PMEs come from; and (c) what special assistance programmes have been rendered to these PMEs aged above 40.

     Dr Ng Eng Hen:

     There were 12,800 unemployed professionals, managers, executives and technicians (PMETs) aged 40 and over in June 2004*.  They constitute 14% of the total of 94,600 unemployed residents who had previous working experience.  The unemployment rate of mature PMETs was 3.8% in June 2004, which is lower than the overall average of 5.5% among residents (excluding those without previous working experience).    

 

     About 8,800 (69%) of mature unemployed PMETs were previously employed in the services sector, 2,800 (22%) were from manufacturing and another 1,100 (9%) from the construction sector.  Within services, these PMETs mainly came from business and real estate (2,400 or 19% of all mature unemployed PMETs), community and personal services (2,300, 18%), and wholesale and retail trade (1,700, 13%).

 

Column: 865

     WDA adopts a multi-pronged approach to enhance the employability of mature PMEs.  Unemployed PMEs are offered advice and career coaching services at the Distributed CareerLink Network of job centres.  In addition, there are conversion programmes to help PMEs take up a new career in other sectors. For instance, the Strategic Manpower Conversion Programme (SMCP) for healthcare prepares mid-career PMEs to make career switches to become registered nurses through an accelerated 2-year diploma programme.  Some 355 PMEs have been successfully placed within various healthcare institutions since the programme started in April 2003. 

 

     WDA also works with our industry partners to provide in-employment upgrading for PMEs in various sectors.  For instance, WDA had worked with employers and the Singapore Hotels Association to develop customised Executive Development Courses to upgrade the skills of executives and managers in the Hotels and F&B sectors.  WDA has also worked with the Media Development Authority (MDA) to train digital media workers to create cutting-edge animation and special effects, and with The Logistic Institute - Asia Pacific (TLIAP), to develop the Supply Chain Management (SCM) Executive Upgrading Programme.


*June 2004 data is the latest for which a breakdown by industry and occupation are available.  June 2005 data will only be ready upon completion of the General Household Survey 2005.

OFF-PEAK CAR SCHEME

     34.   Assoc. Prof. Ong Soh Khim asked the Minister for Transport (a) what is the current percentage of registered vehicles that are registered as off-peak cars; (b) has the Ministry monitored how frequent these off-peak cars have purchased day-licences so as to be used outside the "hours of free usage" as stipulated in the off-peak car scheme; (c) has the off-peak car registration increased or decreased since its implementation; (d) has this off-peak car scheme served its intended purposes; and (e) is this off-peak car scheme still necessary with the current wide use of ERP.

     Mr Yeo Cheow Tong:

     Prof. Ong Soh Khim asked for some information on the Off-Peak Car or OPC Scheme, and whether the scheme is still relevant today.

 

     The OPC scheme was designed to provide car owners with the option to own cars at significantly lower costs if they are prepared to use them sparingly.  Under the scheme, OPC owners are given substantial upfront tax rebates and road tax discounts.  In return, the use of OPCs is restricted to certain time periods.  Since its introduction in September 1994, the total OPC population has been increasing steadily, from about 450 at the end of 1995 to about 8,300 today.  OPCs currently make up about 1.9% of the total car population [or 1.1% of the total vehicle population].

 

     The sale of day licences suggests that OPC owners are using their cars less frequently during the restricted periods.  The number of day licences sold has been decreasing, from about 30 day licences per vehicle per year* in 2000 to about 13 last year.

 

     The increasing take-up of OPCs, coupled with the decrease in sale of day licences, shows that the scheme is popular and has met its intended objective of providing individuals the option of owning cars at a lower cost in exchange for lower usage. It continues to be relevant today, even with the expansion of ERP, because the coverage of ERP is still not island-wide yet.


*The figure covers both Weekend cars and OPCs, which use the same day licence.

ENDANGERED SPECIES (IMPORT AND EXPORT) ACT

(Amendment)

     2.   Dr Geh Min asked the Minister for National Development whether he will consider amending the Endangered Species (Import and Export) Act to serve as a more effective deterrent against illegal wildlife trade by (i) increasing the current fine of $5,000 to a more realistic figure; (ii) amending the Act to a per animal basis, or in the case of animal parts, a quantifiable unit, to replace the present 'per species' penalty that does not represent the true market value of what is traded; and (iii) authorising the detention of specimens that are in transit.

     Mr Mah Bow Tan:

     The Endangered Species (Import and Export) Act was passed in March 1989 to give effect to the Convention on International Trade in Endangered Species of Wild Fauna and Flora, or CITES in short.   Since then, we have amended the Act twice to align it with additional CITES requirements.  In view of the various revisions to CITES recently, we have started another round of review of the Act.  As part of the review, we would consider updating the provisions in the Act on penalties, to maintain effective deterrence.

     For endangered species in transit, the Agri-Food and Veterinary Authority (AVA) currently checks to ensure that the animals and specimens would have the necessary CITES documents for their export from the source country and import into the destination country.  In reviewing the Act, we will also consider whether the existing enforcement procedures are adequate.  We will take into account existing provisions in the Animals and Birds Act, which also empowers AVA to check on animals in-transit, to safeguard animal and public health.

PRIMARY ONE INTAKE IN TAMPINES GRC

(Reduction in 2006)

     4.   Mr Ong Kian Min asked the Minister for Education (a) what are the reasons for reducing 2006 Primary One intake in six popular primary schools in Tampines GRC by between 30 and 60 places; and (b) what measures will be taken to alleviate the transport expenses and inconvenience faced by those children who are affected by the reduced number of places.

     Mr Tharman Shanmugaratnam:

     Generally, the approach taken by MOE in planning the Primary 1 (P1) intake is to provide more than sufficient places for eligible P1 students on both a national and regional basis.  For the 2006 P1 intake, we will have a surplus of 9% of P1 places based on the number of Primary 1 going children on a nationwide basis and a surplus of 12% in Tampines Development Guide Plan (DGP).  All Primary 1 going children will therefore be assured of a place in our primary schools. 

 

     The reduction in intake in some primary schools this year is due to the implementation of a few important initiatives in recent years and in the coming years to improve the quality of primary education.  These include the reduction of class size in Primary 1 and 2 from 40 pupils to 30, and the introduction of partial single session in primary schools.  We have also been giving greater flexibility to schools in how they use some of their space and other infrastructural resources to improve the quality of education, for example, some schools are re-grouping their pupils into different classes according to their strengths. 

 

     To implement these initiatives, we are gradually reducing the Primary 1 intake in schools that currently have a high enrolment.  We recognise that some parents will not be able to get their children into the schools of their initial first choice.  However, their children will have places in schools in the same locality. Like all children, they will benefit from the smaller class sizes and other improvements. 

 

     In providing alternative places for children who are unsuccessful in getting a place in their choice school, we have also minimised the additional travelling distance they have to make from home.

CENTRAL PROVIDENT FUND

(Reduction)

     5.   Assoc. Prof. Ong Soh Khim asked the Minister for Manpower (a) what is the rationale for the progressive reduction of the Central Provident Fund (CPF) contribution rate for the 50-55 age group by 2% from 1st January 2005 and 1st January 2006; and (b) do the employers have to correspondingly reduce the workload of the employees in this age group by 2% as the CPF contribution rate cut is effectively a pay-cut.

Column: 873

     Dr Ng Eng Hen:

     In general, older workers face greater difficulty getting re-employed once they lose their jobs.  The Economic Restructuring Committee (ERC) had noted that one reason for this was wage rigidity in the form of the prevailing seniority-based wage system. This puts older workers at a cost disadvantage compared to younger workers. In addition, older workers have a higher risk of being re-employed at lower pay.

 

     The employer's CPF contribution rate for workers aged 50-55 was thus lowered to enhance wage flexibility and help preserve their jobs. At the same time, the employee CPF contribution rate for this group was lowered to increase their take-home pay.    

 

     We encourage employers to pass on part of their cost savings from the lower CPF to deserving employees in this age group through the variable wage component, such as by giving higher bonuses when the company is doing well.
